SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AND AIM: Two independent post-approval registries have reported favorable periprocedural and short term outcomes with the use of the Wingspan stent for treatment of intracranial arterial stenosis
Data on long term clinical and imaging outcomes after Wingspan stent placement are limited
METHODS: All patients treated with the Wingspan stent in a single academic center from January 2006 to February 2008 were identified
Data on stenting indication, severity of stenosis, technical success, re-stenosis and clinical outcome were collected
RESULTS: 51 patients were treated with the Wingspan stent system for a symptomatic intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis of 50-99%
The mean pre- and post-stent stenoses were 73 (11)% and 21 (7)%
Any stroke or death within 24 h of the procedure occurred in 1/51 (2%)
The frequency of any stroke or death within 30 days or ipsilateral stroke beyond 30 days was 5/51 (10.0%) at a mean follow-up time of 14.6 months (range 8-30)
The frequency of ≥ 50% re-stenosis on follow-up imaging was 7/29 (24%) at 8.6 (4.4) months (range 3-20); all were detected on the initial imaging within 3-6 months, and only one was symptomatic
CONCLUSION: The use of the Wingspan stent in patients with ≥50% symptomatic intracranial stenosis is associated with good long term clinical outcome
One stroke occurred after the first 30 days, suggesting a significant stabilization of the adverse event rate after the first month
